docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Garden has a tumor inside her head -- this much she understands. It will not kill her, she knows, but it has the power to make her miserable and steal her sight. Ms. Garden, 24, also has Medicaid -- sometimes, anyway. And there is much about it that she has just never understood -- the paperwork she gets in the mail, or why the system sometimes insures her and sometimes rejects her, or why she can see some doctors and not others.

headline.main: Trying to Get, and Keep, Care Under Medicaid; Navigating System Takes More Persistence Than Many Clients Have

docs.snippet: The saga of Jennifer Garden, who has a pituitary tumor, illustrates the idiosyncrasies of New York's vast, imperfect Medicaid system.

multimedia.credit: The saga of Jennifer Garden, who has a pituitary tumor, illustrates the idiosyncracies of New York's vast, imperfect Medicaid system.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The saga of Jennifer Garden, who has a pituitary tumor, illustrates the idiosyncracies of New York's vast, imperfect Medicaid system.

multimedia.caption: Struggling to Stay Insured

docs.lead_paragraph: Atop a rise on Burnside Avenue in the Bronx, the Morris Heights Health Center looms above a bustling stretch of storefronts offering arroz con pollo and cheap clothes. The clinic is a crucial medical safety net for tens of thousands of people, many of them struggling. It is a place of solace and deliverance and, just as often, futility and frustration, much of it linked to Medicaid, the government insurance program for the poor.

headline.main: At a Bronx Clinic, High Hurdles for Medicaid Care

docs.abstract: Third article in series, Program Disorder, describes how good intentions of New York's Medicaid program are undermined by inscrutable rules, daunting paperwork, human frailties and puzzling ways state spends program's billions of dollars; many people have trouble getting health care because they do not understand system, especially enrollment process; patients often neglect their care, disregard paperwork or wait until they are seriously ill to apply; many doctors, particularly specialists, shun Medicaid patients, in part because New York ranks at or near bottom among states in what it pays doctors to treat people on Medicaid; New York runs nation's most extravagant Medicaid program, paying $44.5 billion per year to care for 4.2 million people; program, which consumes more than third of state budget, is vulnerable to fraud and abuse by unscrupulous providers; although state does less than other states to police payments to providers, it keenly scrutinizes ordinary patients trying to get into program; detailed look at scene inside Morris Heights Health Center in Bronx, where Medicaid is both daily lifesaver and just so much wasted effort; photos; charts (L)
docs.snippet: A look inside a Bronx clinic illuminates Medicaid's sprawling good works, and how they are undermined by inscrutable rules, daunting paperwork and human frailties.
docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: THE old man in the khaki pants, white high-tops and navy windbreaker crooned a tune of his own composition as he wandered slowly down Buffalo Avenue past a green sedan held together with duct tape. What you say What you gonna doooooo -- They gonna close the hospital. A smiling figure in a black sweatshirt called out to him. ''Hey, you better have good health insurance.'' Without turning his head, the singer continued his ambling toward nowhere in particular. ''Man, I been coming here since Bush was president, the first Bush,'' he remarked. ''But I got the same coverage as Bush, man.''
docs.snippet: Dogged by money woes, St. Mary's Hospital has closed after 123 years in Crown Heights. The mourning has just begun.

multimedia.credit: Dogged by money woes, St. Mary's Hospital has closed its doors after 123 years in Crown Heights. The mourning has just begun.
